title: CEO of Supercell on the Harsh Truth About Game Development

rawLines.text: You've been called a serial killer of
games. I mean, odds are absolutely
against me. Maybe there's like one out
of 10 chance. Maybe there's one out of
20 chance. And you have to be, I guess,
a little bit crazy to kind of work on on
that side of a business. Most of the
games companies were super like
hierarchical was this moment of truth
and and realization. And then they had
this idea that like what if you would
build a completely different type of
games company where you would actually
turn the kind of this organizational
pyramid like you know you would flip it
like we were so lucky that our first
game on Facebook was an absolute
failure. Had it been a success it might
be but Supercell as we know it today
wouldn't even exist. If I would be in
your shoes, the thing that I would not
do is Ila Poninan is the co-founder and
CEO of Supercell, the powerhouse behind
Clash of Clans, Clash Royale, and Brawl
Stars. Ilka built a culture where only
the best ideas survive, with most
projects being cut early to make room
for true breakthroughs. In this speedrun
session, he unpacks Supercell's radical
culture, how to build great teams, and
why taking big risks and ultimately
failing are essential to startups.
One of the the really interesting parts
of Supercell beyond the games is the
culture that has enabled the development
of so many hit games over such a long
period of time as a market has shifted.
So I want to kick this off with uh a
question to Ilka. Uh what has remained
consistent with Supercell's culture over
the past years? Well, hey, first of all,
thank thank you for for having me.
Really great to meet you all and and
congrats to all of all of you guys. Duck
just uh told me how incredibly hard it's
it's to get into speedrun in the first
place. So, as an entrepreneur, like one
of the most exciting things is always
when you get to work, you know, on on
something new and build something from
scratch. So, I'm excited for for you
guys for that. About our culture like um
I think you know we maybe I should go
back to like you know why we founded the
company in the first place because you
know that belief still like is is why we
u it's very much true. So basically like
you know when we founded the company um
almost 15 years ago like there was a
group of six co-founders I was lucky to
be one of them and and you know at that
point in time we already had been in in
the games industry for like roughly 10
years like each of us. So Supercell
wasn't our first games company and it
sort of like at that time especially
like most of the games companies were
super like hierarchical meaning that
essentially like the CEO or the
leadership team like ultimately decided
what type of games the the company would
build and you know our previous
companies including the one that I uh
helped to found and run like was was
exactly uh the same but then and it took
me many many years to realize like
what's what's the fundamental problem uh
in in that model and it it's basically
based on this assumption that the
somehow the CEO or leadership team uh
you know has a kind of crystal ball and
and and really knows what the players
and and and the consumers want. uh and
and then I had this moment of
realization like uh at some point in the
previous company where I realized that
actually like you know despite
everything all the great processes that
I had put uh in in place we we actually
were able to put out some great games
but all of those ga great games like
came somehow like outside that official
process and I realized that that wow
like the company is actually successful
like not because of what I do but
despite everything that I put in place
and it was this moment of truth and and
realization and then they had this idea
that like what if you would build a
completely different type of games
company where you would actually turn
the kind of this organizational pyramid
like you know you would flip it. So
instead of a CEO and the leadership team
owning the kind of vision like what type
of games the company would do like what
it would actually be the game teams
themselves who and each of them would
own kind of the vision of a game and
they could essentially be in complete
control of like what type of game they
would would build and then that sort of
led to this idea that hey we should
actually think about these individual
game teams as like their independent
teams and then somebody had an idea
let's call them cells and that's where a
name supercell comes from but really
Like this is the kind of core of
Supercell Steel today. So we have this
like fun fundamental belief that you
know the team that works on any game
whether it's a new game or a live game
it doesn't matter that that team like
like 100% like owns and controls like
what they do and there can't be any kind
of external forces and and you know
including myself that who can like go in
and and somehow mess mess with what the
team is is is doing. So that that
certainly is still true. And then there
are other things like for example like
we've always had these like very
ambitious goals and dreams for our our
games. So we we like to say that we
always kind of shoot for the moon well
realizing that most of the time you know
we we will fail by doing that. But
that's a at the very core of supercell
you know we want to you know take big
big risks and again knowing that most of
the time we will fail. Um so that's
that's the other thing that I still is
very much true and you've uh you've
written about the fact that one despite
having such a strong culture one of your
early failures was not writing it down
soon enough. So before you answer the
question can we just see a show of hands
who has actually written down their
culture and their values.
So what advice would you give to
founders who have uh you know obviously
everyone has a founding vision and they
have a sense of their culture. Why is it
important given everything that's going
on in a startup to write it down early?
So, one of the biggest mist obviously I
made a huge amount of mistakes, but the
one really big mistake early on was
exactly that. So, we it talked so much
about culture, but we never kind of like
or I didn't I was too busy with other
stuff. I'm sure many of you guys are as
well. And and I we kind of never like
wrote that then them down. It took us I
think two years to get to that point.
and and the and how we actually got to
that point that they realized that then
for example when we talked
responsibility was one of one of our
values and then in one meeting we start
to talk about the responsibilities and
then it turned out that people had like
completely different ideas what that
even means at supercell and and then
that sort of like was the trigger that
that made us like write them down but
the reason and and you know I'm not
talking about you need to have like this
10page or 100 pages like you know
document but but you know try to you
know steal them down to even like you
know one uh just a one sheet or even
like very very si simple like you know
less than 10 slides. But the value of
like writing stuff down is that it kind
of forces you to like formulate and and
describe very very clearly like you know
what those values are and it also forces
like alignment and and and you know and
creates discussion. And one of the uh
the ideas you talk a lot about is the
best teams make the best games which is
how you figure out you know how to pair
people together uh you know initially
when they're they're starting a team to
form a cell. How in the early days did
you find the best talent or the the best
people to make up the best teams
pre-traction when you did not have the
success yet? The basically as I said
there were six co-founders. We had
already been in games for roughly 10
years each. So we actually knew a lot of
people and basically I remember we had
these meetings where we were asking
ourselves like okay who are the very
best people we've ever worked with and
and you know that was basically like how
when they kind of that helped us to like
get maybe the first 20 or 30 people on
on board but by the way that approach
has also like one disadvantage that I
didn't realize at the time because if
you only like recruit for your own
networks and sort of the people that you
like and all that then you can run the
risk of like everybody is a little bit
the game. So I think there's actually
and only later on we realize what's the
value of kind of diversity and and and
it has a massive value and it took us
years to like understand it because it's
it's easily that you like build this
like echo chamber when you just hire
like like-minded people. So, so I would
advise also like sometimes go your out
like from your own own circles and get
people who are just different. And you
uh you write a yearly blog post uh that
kind of talks about you know what
happened over the past year and going
forward you know your vision outlook for
the next year for Supercell and it
usually happens around Q1 around this
time. I'm curious if you have any topics
that you could you know give us a sneak
peek on that you're thinking about. Well
um maybe a few things. So obviously like
u uh last year was incredibly good for
us like one um one of the best years we
we've ever had uh and and and you know
like for example like all of our live
games like grew which I think was the
first time in the history of the company
which is a like unbelievable achievement
from our live game teams and um and
obviously like you know one of the
reasons why that happened is that we
actually like we got over our fears of
like growing these teams. So we we we
had like in previous years we just had
like underinvested into our kind of
games and live game games and and the
teams and the players and that type of
thing and and and by the way the reason
why we didn't do that we were so scared
to of these bigger teams because we you
know like we we were scared that they
would bring in like you know middle
management and processes and bureaucracy
and all that. But then once we finally
got over those fears and start to grow
the company maybe two years ago now we
are going and we now we can just simply
like do more for our players and for the
games and that that u really start to
show actually in the results also last
year. So I'm going to like reflect a
little bit on that and of course the
shining star is is Brawl Stars. It's
I've never seen in my career like a type
of growth for a kind of six-year-old
game and it's been like absolutely
incredible and of course you know we've
been super lucky. I mean luck has play
played a big role but also like the team
has made some like really really great
and bold changes to the to the game. So
I'm going to probably like you know
write something something about that. Uh
and then on the other hand, the other
big uh sort of thing that happened for
us last year was that we we launched
Squadbusters. So like game game number
six and we hadn't launched actually a
game in in a very long time and had a
fantastic start, but then also like
there are clearly like quite a few
issues also with the game that we are
like really working hard to solve. Also,
I'm going to like also talk about that
side of the business and and maybe just
about the fact that how incredibly hard
it actually is to launch new games and
that obviously is true for everybody and
uh and I just actually read this
statistics like when I was like writing
the the blog. Um like the thing is that
that most of the the the kind of the
time spent on games is actually spent on
games that are actually relatively old.
I think more than six years old. But I
if I recall correctly roughly like 60%
of the time goes to goes to games that
are like more than five years old or
more than six more than six years old.
So So that tells you like how incredibly
hard or difficult it is to actually
introduce something new. We'll talk
about that a little bit later. Um I I
want to build on though your point about
needing to grow the teams for the the
games that are actually live operating
uh versus new game teams. And uh I I
understand you you've kind of come come
to the conclusion that team makeup needs
to be quite different for games that are
live versus new game teams. And can you
talk a little bit about what skills are
required for each of those categories?
How you think about that? And uh you
know like how does how does the actual
team composition change as well on on
the new game side? I think the way we
think about it these days is actually
that we we we use this phrase like okay
let's think about new games as their own
startups. In startups, what you need is
basically the best possible team of
entrepreneurs. The way I think about
entrep the best confounders and
entrepreneurs I know like the for
example, one thing that sort of is is
common for all of them is that they can
somehow magically like you know um do
like a lot of things with very little
resources. They can somehow some somehow
like magically things just happen even
though it should be like impossible
because we just don't have any any
resources. So we we want to we look for
those type of people. Obviously you have
to have a very high level of ambition
and and you have to be somehow you need
to get energized about this fact that
okay like what I'm about to build here
uh you know it has the odds of of of
kind of success are it's super low. I
mean the odds are absolutely against me.
Maybe there's like one out of 10 chance.
Maybe there's one out of 20 chance. But
then you have this confidence and you
get energized about it. And for example
in a room like this like you would like
feel sorry for everybody else who are
going to fail because I'm going to
succeed. So you have to almost like live
in your own bubble that yeah of course
you're going to going to succeed even
though that the facts like say that that
you you won't. So it and you have to be
I guess a little bit crazy to kind of
work on on that side of the business. Uh
and on and on and on the live game side,
I mean obviously still like you have to
like the same thing applies in terms of
ambitions, but you also like have to be
like a super super sort of customer or
player centric. You have to like really
like understand the audience and and in
the new game side there's very little
like data points that you can have like
despite what how much focus groups and
stuff you do but you have to have very
strong intuition like what you're trying
to build on the live game side. I think
there's the data and these insights play
a much bigger role and you have to be
the type of person who actually like
takes all of those inputs in and then of
course you still have a gut feel and
then you make decisions but uh but you
have to be like I think more driven by
the the kind of the audience and
understand the audience etc and and then
you know to continue the live games and
obviously they are much bigger teams so
you know somewhere in the teams you have
to have this like people who are great
at operations you know they must be
organized of course the variety of
skills that the live game teams need is
way different. So it's not just game
development the typical crafts like you
know coding and art and design it it's
it's also like stuff like you know
analytics uh monetization you know live
operations uh and and and those type of
things. So extending the startup analogy
live games are almost like startups with
product market fit essentially. Yeah
scaleups essentially. Yes. uh you know
when you were early on in development
you were actually in the web game space
and there was a critical moment where
you decided decided to pivot to tablets
and then eventually mobile. Can you tell
us that story and what signals did you
see that really gave you the confidence
to make the switch in your development?
Yeah, I mean that obviously was a great
decision at the time and and and uh but
I would say that you know again I
oftentimes I talk about like the role of
luck and this is kind of perfect example
like we were so lucky that our first
game on Facebook was an absolute failure
because and you know if you think about
it had it been a success it might be
that Supercell as we know it today
wouldn't even exist. But you know that
failure like forced us to get back to
the drawing board and really like think
like okay like you know clearly this
isn't working like what you know and and
what should we be doing differently and
then somehow like like some people had
gotten their first iPads which is
relatively new device at the time and
and I was one of them and we fell in
love with the device and and but
realized actually not that many great
games especially not great of social
games are available for the device and
and most of these games are based just
ports from like a you desktop and and we
wanted to like create experiences that
they called they're like truly social
and in heyday you know we had like this
trading mechanic and later on like
people could play together in
neighborhoods etc etc u so that's that's
that's sort of how we kind of thought
about it but again like obviously we got
super lucky with the timing like it was
exactly the right time to start to do
that and and back then back in that day
like this is like 2011 we actually had
to like convince people that you know
free-to-play games are even real games.
I I remember like I was visiting GDC and
and showing the first version of Clash
of Clans and people would literally play
that game and say that asked me that I I
don't understand like why would anybody
play this game? It's not even a game. Uh
and and that's how like different you
know freeto play felt to kind of the
traditional sort of a game develop
development industry at the at the time.
But somehow because we but then we could
show that game like people who came from
outside the industry. So we're real
players and and there was a lot of
excitement about the game. So then that
kind of gave us conviction to continue.
You've been uh called uh not you
specifically but Supercell has been
called a serial killer of games and
that's because uh only a very small
percentage of the games that are
developed are are killed and some of
them very publicly. Um can you talk to
the team here about how you think about
product quality? what are the gates that
you know basically you think about when
getting a game ready to launch and how
has that changed over time as the market
shifted? Yeah, this is a great question
actually something that is very topical
for us right now because you know it you
know it used to be I shouldn't say easy
but it was at at least more
straightforward. So we had this very
simple rules like stuff like okay that
the day 30 retention must be above 20%
at scale and and you know and those type
and and they always always have been big
believers and actually still are that
the most important thing that you you
want to find is is you know and what you
need to focus on early on is like
basically all of these retention and
engagement metrics because if those
metrics are strong I mean then you have
something that people truly like care
about and they love and then the
monetization actually isn't as important
because as time goes by you'll figure
out some some ways to kind of monetize
also that that usage. But the problem is
that at least like and what they learned
from squad is that it's uh at least in
our scale it's it's extremely difficult
to kind of forecast like what might be
or extrapolate like from the uh sample
sizes that you have like okay like how
how how like you know how will these
metrics look like at scale to give you
guys an idea like at squadbusters the
latest sort of kind of close test that
they had had more than 100,000 100,000
players in it and we felt that they had
a really good handle on on the metrics,
but then all of a sudden then you get to
like tens and tens and tens of millions
of players then those metrics actually
change and the audience changes and and
and all that and so given all the
learnings that you have and how
difficult it is to launch a new game or
even a new app or new product in today's
market. What advice would you give to
the teams here as they are building
their product and you know getting their
first customer, their hundth customer,
their thousandth customer and and
eventually product market fit. Do you
have any kind of tips and tricks or
thoughts on what they should consider?
If I would be in your shoes, the thing
that I would not do is that don't go to
the, you know, uh, top grossing chart
and and pick a game from there and say,
"Okay, we're going to build a better
version of this." because I I I think
that that's going to be extremely
extremely difficult. So, you know, as I
said when we kind of start to build
Supercell, we were in this lucky place
that you know you know I mean Mark's uh
uh farm is a great great example. It
didn't exist on mobile but but but
obviously like you know like it it had
proven that this farm themed games can
be super successful because a massive
hit on on Facebook and and for a good
reason. It was a you know great game. Uh
but then that sort of gave us an
inspiration but hey you know if it's
it's such a big sort of a genre on
Facebook like why wouldn't it be on on
on mobile and then but there but the we
came from a we had this advantage that
we the we farming games at the time on
say iPad and mobile they're actually
like not not that great games. Um so
when you can bring something that's like
you know 100 times better you know like
then you will start to get traction. But
today it's it's much harder to do it.
And I I think sometimes these games, you
know, like say take Monopoly Go or Candy
Crush Saga or any of these games, they
like from surface like some people might
oh think that oh these are actually
relatively simple games and you know
anybody could build this but that's not
true at all. I mean it's incredibly
difficult to build like you know quality
experiences like like them. So so maybe
that's the one thing. So what I would do
is that you know try to build something
that introduces something new to the
players. And I think you just have to
take a lot of risk you know I mean some
people have this illusion that hey you
know let's kind of play it safe you know
let's take this proven concept and then
we're going to add this this thing to
this game and very rarely I mean of
course there are exceptions to the rule
but very rarely it actually works. So go
crazy you know build something that
doesn't exist would be my advice. And uh
everyone in this room, all the founders
are working on their pitches. We have
demo day coming up and uh you led the uh
you know all of the investment rounds
for uh the pitches for Supercell in the
early days and beyond. You're an
investor yourself and also Supercell
Invests in companies. Uh what advice do
you have for everyone here as they're
thinking about building their pitch?
What should they do? What shouldn't they
do? The way I would approach is that
first of all like talk about the your
ambition, talk about the dream and and
um one of the best advices that I got
like back in the day is that you know
when you're kind of forming your vision
for the for the company like you know
create the bold is the biggest vision
you can and once you've done it like
then 10 exit and then you know and and
and and keep on like growing and the
vision like until it it feels that it's
going to be impossible to reach this but
you know that u and and you know in
super's case it the our kind of vision
was that we wanted to create these games
that are remembered forever. So we
talked about companies like say Nintendo
like we talked about brands like Zelda
and Mario and we wanted to you know be
in that class of companies and you know
it's very clear that even today we have
like long long way to uh go if you ever
want to get there. Uh but but that's
kind of our northstar. But you know have
have a a kind of very ambitious vision
that hopefully like somehow stands out
and and the the reason why our vision at
at the time stood out was that you know
because casual games were known for this
like kind of one hit wonders or kind of
lots of people called them like snack
entertainment because you know a a back
in 2010 like a game would chewed up the
app the app store charts and then you
know months later nobody would even
remember that game anymore. So they had
a very like short lifespans and and we
wanted to like change and we wanted to
truly create these games that people
play for years and years and years. Um
so um so that was our vision at the
time. So like and and in today's world
you know obviously it probably has to be
something different because what I just
say isn't different anymore because
everybody is doing that or at least
trying to do that. So uh big vision uh
very high level ambition um uh and and
make it very very clear and then just
you know talk about the team like what
makes your team great because I mean I
think plans at at at the stage that you
guys are at they have very little value.
Of course you have to have a plan but
every like good investor will know that
the plan will change like in two weeks
time as you learn more. So a plan
actually as such has very little value
but um but what has value is u and the
plan doesn't really matter if you have
the right people the right team. So if
there's any kind of proof points that
you can actually prove to the investor
that hey this actually is a a really
really great team uh and and if there's
any kind of like a track record or or
you know you know something that can
proves that the case um you know those
those two things are most important. So,
you know, very bold vision and then, you
know, just proof that this is a
fantastic team. Is there anything that
everyone here should definitely not do?
Anything you've seen in pitches that you
haven't liked? Well, I it's just me, so
I and maybe you guys think differently,
but uh but I I don't like pitches that
um like talk about like exit strategy.
So I I at least I I just can't get
excited about uh companies which like
when you're confounding the company
you're already thinking like okay this
is you know how I'm going to sell it to
someone and and you know sometimes I see
pitches where even like name companies
or here are five potential buyers and I
just don't get excited about it at all
but maybe it's just me because I want to
I I think what this world needs is new
great like independent companies not you
know just companies to be sold and and I
also like I would worry that if I get
the sense that ultimately like what
drives is the founder is just this idea
of like making money. Uh I I think it's
absolutely the wrong reason to found a a
company because first of all the
likelihood that you will make money is
actually relatively low. Uh uh it
probably doesn't happen. I mean odds are
against you and if you don't if and and
I I think you know the passion has to
come from the fact that okay I want to
build something great and and I want to
build something great for for my users
my you know my customers my players. Um,
so I so so that's you know how how I
think about it. So zooming out and

like because just more efficient to

least so like you know like I I think

example Tik Tok and and different type

uh yeah let's dig into generative AI for

Supercell's early days where the idea is

move quickly launch uh what do you think

well. how how we think about AI is

So like I mean obviously like AI in

yes now these teams are slightly bigger

and on the new game side we we still

so AI clearly can help as you said these

that's that's going to be um good. But
then I I think the even more exciting
